The Birthplace of Herbert Hoover, West Branch, Iowa, 1931 (oil on masonite)

700275 The Birthplace of Herbert Hoover, West Branch, Iowa, 1931 (oil on masonite) by Wood, Grant (1891-1942); 75.2x101 cm; Minneapolis Institute of Arts, MN, USA; (add.info.: Herbert Clark Hoover (August 10, 1874 - October 20, 1964) was the 31st President of the United States (1929-1933). Hoover, born to Quaker parents of German, Swiss, Canadian and Irish descent, was originally a professional mining engineer and author. He achieved American and international prominence in humanitarian relief efforts and served as head of the U.S. Food Administration before and during World War I); eMinneapolis Institute of Art; Purchased jointly by The Minneapolis Institute of Arts and the Des Moines Art Center; with funds from the John R. Van Derlip Fund, Mrs. Howard H. Frank, and the Edmundson Art Foundation, Inc.; American, out of copyright

The Birthplace of Herbert Hoover, West Branch, Iowa, 1931

EDITORS COMMENTS

is a captivating oil painting by Grant Wood that depicts the humble beginnings of the 31st President of the United States. The artwork showcases a picturesque farmhouse nestled in the idyllic countryside of rural Iowa. Wood's meticulous brushwork and attention to detail bring this provincial scene to life. The vibrant colors and stylized composition evoke a sense of nostalgia for simpler times. As we gaze upon this painting, we are transported back to an era when farming was at the heart of American society. Herbert Hoover's birthplace holds great significance in understanding his journey from being a mining engineer to becoming one of America's most influential leaders. This artwork not only captures the physical essence of his childhood home but also symbolizes his deep-rooted connection to agriculture and rural values. Through "The Birthplace". Wood pays homage to both Hoover's personal history and the Midwestern landscape that shaped him. It serves as a reminder that even those who rise to positions of power often carry with them their humble origins. This remarkable piece is part of the collection at Minneapolis Institute of Arts, where it stands as a testament to Wood's artistic prowess and ability to capture slices of American life with authenticity and charm.
